page.title: 11DE HAVILLAND COLLEGE
page.content: De Havilland College, previously Mid-Herts College was opened by Princess Anne on 29 November 1960. Originally it was built adjoining the Welwyn Garden City main library but the library grew too big and was moved into Campus West. The name Mid-Herts College was changed to de Havilland College because de Havillands at Hatfield was taken over by the Hawker Siddeley Company and later was nationalised and its name changed to British Aerospace. The college was called de Havilland College to commemorate Sir Geoffrey de Havilland, the founder of the aircraft company. The current principal is G J Evans. The college has 1,000 students and runs business studies, computer, engineering, technology and science courses. The college also has two refectories and a gymnasium.
